By KEN ZIERLER

George Washington Natators
Host To Hambletonites
At Shoreham Hotel Pool

Hopkins Confident
Black And Blue Swimmers
Seek Season's First Win;
Frosh Face Central High
George Washington U. will play
host to the Jays tomorrow night in
the latter's fourth tank meet of the
season at the Shoreham Hotel pool in
Washington. Victory has eluded the
Hopkins natators in all three of their
encounters so far, and Coach Hambleton's charges are determined to
finally enter into the win column tomorrow.
Hopkins last year nosed out the
Capital swimmers in the K. of C.
, pool, through victory in the final
event, the relay, and a close battle is
anticipated in the coming meeting.
George Washington will be especially
desirous of turning the tables on the
Black and Blue, as the Jays have won
consistently in the past few years.
The District team this season is
led by Dyer Ghormely, star breaststroke and diver who, in 1934, succeeded in placing in the former event
at the Eastern Intercollegiate Championships. Bill Hazlett, who represents the Jays in the breaststroke, has
been defeated only once this year, and
an exciting contest should result between the two natators. Bill Koenig
and Bill McConnell will match dives
for Hopkins against the District ace.
Another George Washington star
is Carter, a transfer from Duke, who
stood out in the distances there, placing high in these events in the Southern Conference Championships. Teaming up with several other capable natators, he forms the nucleus for a formidable entry in the "220" and "440".
Lou and Bud Adler, Dan Weiner, and
Don Noonan are the mermen who will
compete in these races for Hopkins.
In the backstroke Weiner and John
MacGill should tally well for the
Black and Blue. Both have performed
the 150-yard sprint in time that is
under the Hopkins record, and the
two swimmers are expected to secure the first two positions in this
event tomorrow night.
Hopkins also hopes to pick up a
number of points in the sprints. Max
Rote of George Washington, who
gained second in the Eastern Intercollegiate 100 last year, has in the
past successfully obstructed this desire of the Jays. However, with his
graduation in 1934, the Capital natators have lost a large proportion of
their strength in the dashes. Lou Adler, Charlie Jones, John MacGill, and
Noonan perform in the sprints for the
Black and Blue and combine to form
the relay quartet in the last and usually the deciding event of the meet.
Concurrently with the varsity encounter, the freshman team will meet
Central High School of Washington in
the same pool. The freshmen have
dropped contests to Friends and Calvert Hall, and are given only an outside chance to top the strong Central
aggregation. Goodman, Moses, Jacobs, Garden, Vincenti, and Hill stand
out for the Jays.

Frat Captains
Change Rules
Basketball, Volleyball Leagues Reformed At Meeting; Four
Rules Adopted
In an effort to reform the Interfraternity Basketball and Volleyball
Leagues, a meeting of the team captains was held at which the following rules were adopted:
1. Any fraternity not having its
team ready to play at the designated
date and time shall lose by a forfeit
unless Ed Lotz or Frank DotterweiM
are notified 24 hours in advance that
the team will not be there.
2. If neither team shows up, the
game will be dropped from the schedule and no points will be awarded
either team.
3. In cases where notification is
given 24 hours in advance, the games
will be rescheduled at a later date.
4. Notification of cancellation can
be given to Lotz or Dotterweich by
phoning University 0100, Extension
45, around 1:00 p. m., or through
Postoffice Box No. 670.

Shatter Jays' Title Aspirations

By KEN ZIERLER

George Washington Natators
Host To Hambletonites
At Shoreham Hotel Pool

Hopkins Confident
Black And Blue Swimmers
Seek Season's First Win;
Frosh Face Central High
George Washington U. will play
host to the Jays tomorrow night in
the latter's fourth tank meet of the
season at the Shoreham Hotel pool in
Washington. Victory has eluded the
Hopkins natators in all three of their
encounters so far, and Coach Hambleton's charges are determined to
finally enter into the win column tomorrow.
Hopkins last year nosed out the
Capital swimmers in the K. of C.
, pool, through victory in the final
event, the relay, and a close battle is
anticipated in the coming meeting.
George Washington will be especially
desirous of turning the tables on the
Black and Blue, as the Jays have won
consistently in the past few years.
The District team this season is
led by Dyer Ghormely, star breaststroke and diver who, in 1934, succeeded in placing in the former event
at the Eastern Intercollegiate Championships. Bill Hazlett, who represents the Jays in the breaststroke, has
been defeated only once this year, and
an exciting contest should result between the two natators. Bill Koenig
and Bill McConnell will match dives
for Hopkins against the District ace.
Another George Washington star
is Carter, a transfer from Duke, who
stood out in the distances there, placing high in these events in the Southern Conference Championships. Teaming up with several other capable natators, he forms the nucleus for a formidable entry in the "220" and "440".
Lou and Bud Adler, Dan Weiner, and
Don Noonan are the mermen who will
compete in these races for Hopkins.
In the backstroke Weiner and John
MacGill should tally well for the
Black and Blue. Both have performed
the 150-yard sprint in time that is
under the Hopkins record, and the
two swimmers are expected to secure the first two positions in this
event tomorrow night.
Hopkins also hopes to pick up a
number of points in the sprints. Max
Rote of George Washington, who
gained second in the Eastern Intercollegiate 100 last year, has in the
past successfully obstructed this desire of the Jays. However, with his
graduation in 1934, the Capital natators have lost a large proportion of
their strength in the dashes. Lou Adler, Charlie Jones, John MacGill, and
Noonan perform in the sprints for the
Black and Blue and combine to form
the relay quartet in the last and usually the deciding event of the meet.
Concurrently with the varsity encounter, the freshman team will meet
Central High School of Washington in
the same pool. The freshmen have
dropped contests to Friends and Calvert Hall, and are given only an outside chance to top the strong Central
aggregation. Goodman, Moses, Jacobs, Garden, Vincenti, and Hill stand
out for the Jays.

Frat Captains
Change Rules
Basketball, Volleyball Leagues Reformed At Meeting; Four
Rules Adopted
In an effort to reform the Interfraternity Basketball and Volleyball
Leagues, a meeting of the team captains was held at which the following rules were adopted:
1. Any fraternity not having its
team ready to play at the designated
date and time shall lose by a forfeit
unless Ed Lotz or Frank DotterweiM
are notified 24 hours in advance that
the team will not be there.
2. If neither team shows up, the
game will be dropped from the schedule and no points will be awarded
either team.
3. In cases where notification is
given 24 hours in advance, the games
will be rescheduled at a later date.
4. Notification of cancellation can
be given to Lotz or Dotterweich by
phoning University 0100, Extension
45, around 1:00 p. m., or through
Postoffice Box No. 670.
